reviewText: This is a movie I've enjoyed numerous times and will look forward to adding it to my BD Collection - it's truly deserving of Blu Ray treatment.The casts blends so well and it blows away the Westerns I viewed growing up.  Historically they likely weren't so cool and attractive in reality but they do a job of matching what our minds may have perceived who these folks were in the Wild West.  There's a little bit of everything in this film.It's sad that a Amazon Reviewer comes into Amazon and trashes a movie because it's not a Directors Cut.  Considering the age of the film now perhaps they had no DC as all the extra content has become expanded with BD capability but he should never have trashed the film because he didn't favor the type of cut - one has nothing to do with the other - if it's not the version you want don't buy it but trashing it with your rating is childish and selfish at best! Others take heed where reviewers abuse their responsibility in posting ratings and his is an abuse of that privilege!
summary: A Best Western IMO that is timeless

reviewText: Original story, extremely well told.The all star cast delivers academy worthy performances.The eye to detail of period specific costumes, make-up, sets were far above what I have seen in a long time.They even sprinkled in a little bit of old west word and speech patterns to help authenticate the movie.Some movies over do that and you are left watching the movie with only a vague understanding of what people are saying.If you wanted to own one cowboy movie, I recommend this be your choice.
summary: Best Cowboy Movie made since John Wayne died

reviewText: TOMBSTONE (1993) remains one of the most widely hyped, widely adored films in history. I find it to be one of the best Westerns ever made, and when you get a whiff of the backstory, you'll agree. I think right off the bat we can say this film succeeded because of the gaudy-yet-riveting Kurt Russell (Wyatt Earp) and Val Kilmer (Dr. John "Doc" Holliday).This thing as horse operas go is really an old-fashioned cowboy's dream entertainment. While it shamelessly stole from its father, WYATT EARP (vid. my review), it managed to spring the Western back into unprecedented popularity. Also it grossed double whatWyatt Earpdid. It told a fanciful, colorful Earp chapter (restricted to the legendary fight in Tombstone) and it did so with panache, great humor, style, flair and unmatched beauty. Both symbolically and texturally, TOMBSTONE really delivers. It is funny, daring, unconventional and can be deeply moving.It covers the Earp Family's time in Tombstone, centering on the famous street fight, and though it goes overboard with some silly, unnecessary characters (such as Jason Priestly as the gay Billy Breckenridge and Billy Zane as The-Gay-Caballero or whatever he's called who becomes Priestly's love interest), it is good fun. Charleton Heston made an impression here as well.These guys started out with Costner. There was a disagreement, and they split away from Costner's bloated project. After this, Costner made it a living hell for them to finish TOMBSTONE, though as I say, they stole from WYATT EARP, too. The result was critics praising TOMBSTONE for being the first of its kind as an "independent" film. It was "independent" because Costner forced the issue - but he had good right to do so. The producers of TOMBSTONE did not need to steal so much from Costner, then race to beat him to the box office, but I guess bad blood is bad blood.Anyway, do not miss the delicious fun, the over-the-top silliness of the lisping, wisecrackin' Doc Holliday - and the steadfast rock Kurt Russell is, serving to anchor this film. I don't know why but the true clan leader, Virgil (Sam Elliot) is made to look a bit weak and unhinged. Virgil was the family's rock in real life, often the only man who could control Wyatt's losses of temper.They got all that wrong here, but that's the fun of horse opera for horse opera's sake. You'll see why it is considered one of the best films of all time, even if it isn't.
summary: It ain't just a good pizza! You're a daisy if you do!

reviewText: Opening on Christmas Day in 1993, Kurt Russell and Val Kilmer's "Tombstone" film enjoyed more than a half-year's head start on rival Kevin Costner's similar (and far more expensive) pet project, "Wyatt Earp." Largely through word of mouth, they easily won the battle of the box office. In terms of pure entertainment, the romanticized "Tombstone" deserved to win, at least at that time because it carefully treaded the line between an adult Western melodrama (hence, the R rating) and often cartoony but vintage Hollywood clichés, making it appealing to a very wide range of audiences. Its ominous poster tagline, "Justice is Coming," spells out perfectly the old-school Western that the movie is.In recent years, star Russell has purportedly admitted to secretly directing "Tombstone" using credited director George Cosmatos as an artistic front after original writer-director Kevin Jarre was dismissed. Assuming that is a fact, it makes sense why "Tombstone" so often resembles a classic Western, since Russell is such an old pro dating back to his childhood working in this genre. Using his expertise, there are several thematic choices that are simplistically brilliant here. The four that most come to mind are: 1. asserting Wyatt Earp as a biblical-like Pale Horseman in which death, hell, and justice will follow in his wake; and 2. assigning trademark red sashes to the villainous Clanton-Curly Bill gang, so viewers can easily distinguish the good guys from the bad. Obviously, no real Old West desperado would have sought that kind of unwanted legal attention, but it works really well for Hollywood's frontier mobsters in this movie who just don't care about anonymity.The third important choice is focusing the film equally on Wyatt and "Doc" Holliday. Although Russell coolly has more screen time, Kilmer's flamboyant, rakish take on the tubercular Holliday steals the show. Yet, by working together, the two actors effectively balance out each other's performances. The relatively solid all-star ensemble cast, including old hand Sam Elliott, Bill Paxton, Dana Wheeler-Nicholson, Powers Boothe, Michael Biehn, Stephen Lang (a dead-on Ike Clanton), and even a cameo from Charlton Heston conveys the ambiance of an old-school Western complete with mustache-twirling villains and reluctant ex-lawmen putting the silver badge on again. The major casting problem lies with Morgan and Virgil's indistinctive blonde wives (who don't have any presence or dialogue) and more so with romantic co-lead Dana Delany. While Delany enjoys some solid chemistry with Russell, she is miscast as a frisky, young Josephine Marcus, since the real Josie Marcus evidently wasn't anything like her.Lastly, the fourth factor is correctly presenting names and accepted historical events in the right order while heavily embellishing other "facts" about the great Earp & Holliday-Clanton feud that ignited the legendary Gunfight at the OK Corral and its bloody aftermath. "Tombstone" also benefits from a majestic, well-balanced musical score from Bruce Broughton, and the fact that the filmmakers strove to make their Arizona location shooting (in Tucson) as colorful as possible, even with a close recreation of Tombstone itself.The film clearly stumbles when the various cliches (too many to mention) start piling up so close together that you don't need to know the historical back story to sense what is coming next. Also, because of the huge ensemble cast, many characters (i.e. Jason Priestley's Deputy Sheriff Billy Breckenridge) are under-developed or so one-dimensional that the script treats them like mere after-thoughts. You may also notice some occasional spots where the actors (including Billy Zane's efforts and Russell's wooden last line to Kilmer) sink into stilted melodrama, which erodes their overall performances. As I stated in my review of "Wyatt Earp," I honestly believe that, had these rival productions actually worked together by pooling all their mighty resources, a better and more profitable film would have resulted.Rating: 7.5/10 (In terms of sheer entertainment value, "Tombstone" trumps the plodding "Wyatt Earp," despite its heavy reliance on traditional Western clichés and some weak performances. If they are compared side by side, I would consider the two films as roughly even with an edge to Costner's film for technical merits).P.S. The impressive blu-ray special features are pretty solid entertainment and quite fun to watch.
summary: "Tombstone": A Grand Old-School Western for Modern Audiences

reviewText: How many films on this subject have made it to the Big Screen...before I can review the 1993 release "TOMBSTONE"...let's take a look at some of the worthy film releases regarding that Gunfight at the O.K. Corral, from the '40s up to the present in the next few paragraphs of this review."My Darlin' Clementine"(1946) - One of the greatest directors of our time John Ford gave this role of Wyatt Earp(Henry Fonda)...Doc Holliday(Victor Mature) featuring a well-rounded cast of Walter Brennan, Ward Bond, Tim Holt, Linda Darnell and John Ireland...Ford well known for his Westerns, filmed and documented one of the best from Tinsel-Town regarding the O.K. Corral."Gunfight at the O.K. Corral"(1957) - Typical Hollywood Superstar cast, with two hunks in the leading roles of Earp(Burt Lancaster) and Holliday(Kirk Douglas) with an outstanding performance by Jo Van Fleet and the guiding hand of John Sturges in the directors chair...haunting score by composer Dimitri Tiomkin with Frankie Laine singing the opening song."Hour Of The Gun"(1967) - Once again director John Sturges sits behind the camera...the roles of Earp(James Garner) and Holliday(Jason Robards Jr - is excellent as the crusty gambling Doctor) supporting cast is Robert Ryan, Albert Salmi and Jo Voight, with two good actors in the lead...this film lacks the punch of the 1946 outing...please note:Jerry Goldsmith composed the filmscore."Wyatt Earp"(1994) - Filmed in Sante Fe, New Mexico...director Lawrence Kasdan had a fine cast to start with...Earp(Kevin Kostner) and Holliday(Dennis Quaid)...supporting cast Gene Hackman, Mark Harmon, Bill Pullman, Isabella Rossellini and Tom Sizemore...doesn't work well, too long with mixed feelings of a TV miniseries.Now we have the Saga at hand of the legendary lawman with a dynamic cast...from heroes to villains recounting the events prior and up to the O.K. Corral."Tombstone"(1993) - More than any other film on this subject, director George P. Cosmatos captures the mood and friendship between Earp(Kurt Russell) and Holliday(Val Kilmer-with an Oscar Contender Performance)...Virgil Earp(Sam Ellott) and Morgan Earp(Bill Paxton) believable as the loyal lawman brothers...but the highlight of the film is the colorful performances by the villains Ike Clanton(Stephen Lang)...Curly Bill(Powers Boothe)...Johnny Ringo(Michael Biehn)...each making a statement within the boundaries of their chosen vocation and roles...the final showdown by each character is "Cinema" at its finest hour...this 2-DVD-Set has additional extras "Making An Authentic Western", entire cast with behind the scene interviews about the legends and characters during this time in the American West...each cast member talks about his or her particular role, very insightive to say the least...brilliant captivating score by composer Bruce Broughton, brings color to the Western skies and excitement to dusty trails of Tombstone, during the hard riding scenes, Broughton's soundtrack puts you on horseback galloping for more excitement you can handle, so lets slap leather and head for town...TOMBSTONE!, gotta love it.Total Time: 134 Minutes ~ Hollywood Pictures Home Video 23118 ~ (1993/2002-Directors Cut)

reviewText: Tombstone is probably THE most overrated movie ever made.  George Cosmotos couldn't land any decent directing gigs since Rambo First Blood Part 2 and thankfully won't direct a movie again (RIP).  This movie is a collection of unfinished scenes starring respectable actors who have no idea they are in the hands of a hack.  Only people who like American Beauty, Pulp Fiction, and Office Space will be attracted to this trash.  Get ready for two hours of your life you will NEVER get back.  Michael Beihn and Val Kilmer chew through their scenes with immense energy (and are worth watching) but they can't save this deflated and uninteresting turd.  Is this disc any good?  Who cares?!  Don't waste your time or your money--or wait for it to hit the $5.00 bin at Wal-Mart.

reviewText: This movie was released at nearly the same time as the movie entitled Wyatt Earp.  I met Wyatt Earp and when I asked him where he got that name he said, "It is an old family name."  He said he was a descendent of the famous Wyatt Earp.  I asked him if he saw the 2 movies which were shown on TV.  I asked his impression of the 2 movies and if he thought they were accurate.  He said "they are substantially accurate but some features were added for effect.  They did not typify his ancestor."  He purchased the lot to build his house from my brother.  I lived in the same town in Iowa where he built his house in 3 different periods for a total of 10 years.  The movie depicts many famous persons and events in history during the era of the original Wyatt Earp.

reviewText: Ignore those reviews lamenting that this Blu-ray may not be the Directors Cut.  I've seen both and both deserve 5 stars.  I would, however, wish that Amazon was providing some details of the extras included on the disc.  "Tombstone" is one of a very few westerns of the past 25 years that belongs on list of Great Westerns.  Everything works amazingly well in this movie from script, cast, sound track and even direction.  I say "even direction" because the story behind the direction of "Tombstone" has become legend itself.  Who really was responsible for what is seen remains a mystery.  I like the theory that Kurt Russell was ultimately the man behind the movie but the truth remains elusive.  Without a doubt this is the best work ever done by Val Kilmer and he does steal many scenes in the film.  However, I would also rate this as Kurt Russell's best work and he holds the focus of the story from beginning to end and has many standout moments.  The remainder of the cast is truly remarkable and helps to add great depth to the experience.  All this reflects the original movie and previous DVD's and not the Blu-ray which I don't expect to see until "Opening Day."  I'll update this review after seeing the latest version of "Tombstone" and hope that it will meet my expectations.

reviewText: Over the years I have seen this film many many times, but ironically never owned the DVD, as for a long time it wasn't available. Fortunately this has enabled me to get the blu-ray edition without having to replace a DVD.The film: Most of us know the story which revolves around the famous shoot-out at the OK Corral. In my view this is the best of the many film versions you can get. The reasons are many, but Val Kilmers performance as Doc Holliday is first on the list. His delivery of some classic lines and his look are quite brilliant. Rest assured there some other teriffic performances, but his is the best by quite a margin. The direction is straightforward and the script keeps you guessing nicely in places. Sometimes the obvious doesn't happen.....Flaws: Its perhaps a little too long at 2:10 and maybe could have been trimmed a little. But I can't think where though, so this is a minor point.The Blu-ray: Overall this is a very good transfer to blu-ray. The picture is very sharp and the sound excellent. Only in a couple of interior shots could I fault the picture, where I thought it was a little grainy. Obviously I don't have a DVD to compare the blu-ray with but I'd be very surprised if its anywhere near as good overall.Extras: Not substantial, but there is a very good documentary with some comparitively recent interviews with the cast and some interesting historical background to the events portrayed and the lengths the production team went for historical accuracy. For example they used the actual Wyatt Earp Peacemaker in the film (his gun).Overall: 5 stars no question!

reviewText: I rented on strength of reviews but could not get very far into this mess of a movie. The music is so corny it ruins what grit there might actually be in this over-stylized account of a piece of American history. Too bad the great cast was given such a poor script and ho-hum direction; you can predict the whole thing from the start.If you want realism, try the new version of "True Grit" or "Unforgiven" or the series "Deadwood," and some others. All the rest pale in comparison. Now I realize some like their westerns with "Miss Kitty" atmosphere and that is fine. This is that movie. Just don't expect any true grit here.
summary: Nah, don't bother unless you like your western "Hollywood" style...

reviewText: After I struggled through Wyatt Earp, my friends all recommended this movie to me. Apparently Kurt Russel is a better actor than Kevin Costner and Val Kilmer's Doc Holiday is just amazing. So I finally watched it and it wasn't all that great.Of course Doc Holliday is the best character in this storyline and he will always be the best character, but I found Dennis Quaid a better Doc Holiday (if only because he was saving us from Kevin Costner's delivery) Val Kilmer just seems pretentious where Dennis Quaid was having fun. Kurt Russel is ok, but this movie is also ponderous and too long.Besides that the video transfer isn't very good. Half the time it looks like everyone is walking around in a dust cloud. While that brings some authenticity to the old west storyline it doesn't bring much pleasure to the viewer at home. If you want to watch this movie, get the DVD. I can't say that it's any better, but it can't be any worse.

reviewText: This movie is enjoyable all the way through and has some really good memorable lines from the characters. Kurt Russell is good as Wyatt Earp but the stand out in this movie is hands down Val Kilmer. There is not another actor I can think of that could have played the part of Doc Holliday any better. His Georgian accent is realistic and believable and his acting was as on point as it could get. Much better than the movie Wyatt Earp mainly because it had a better overall cast. Russell, Kilmer, Elliot, Paxton just did it right. Well made and entertaining. Watch this movie it will be your huckleberry!
summary: One of the best westerns ever made.
